subject: Photography
title: Reading Light Before Shooting
description: A micro-lesson that makes Reading Light Before Shooting usable.

hook.text: Before you raise the camera, stop. Look at the light. Where is it coming from? What quality is it? What color?

buildup.text: Professional photographers assess direction, quality, color, and intensity of light before taking a single shot.

discovery.text: Ask three questions: Where are the shadows falling? How hard or soft are the edges? What color is the light?

twist.text: Most beginners look at the subject first. Experts look at the light first. The subject is secondary.

climax.text: Learning to read light takes practice, not equipment. It's free, and it's the skill that elevates every photo.

punchline.text: See the light first. Then see the subject.

quiz.question: What should a photographer assess before raising the camera?
options: The direction, quality, color, and intensity of the light
